conversation.content: How to suppress background noise in OBS Studio?

To suppress background noise in OBS Studio, follow these steps:

1. Open OBS Studio and click on the gear icon in the bottom-right corner to open the settings.

2. In the settings menu, click on the "Audio" tab.

3. Under the "Devices" section, you will find options to select your input and output devices. Make sure your microphone is selected as the input device.

4. Click on the "Filters" button under the "Microphone/Auxiliary Audio Device" section.

5. In the filters window, click on the "+" button to add a new filter.

6. Select "Noise Gate" from the list of available filters.

7. In the Noise Gate settings, adjust the "Close Threshold" slider to determine at what level the microphone should activate and start picking up sound. Set it to a level slightly above the background noise.

8. Adjust the "Open Threshold" slider to determine at what level the microphone should deactivate and stop picking up sound. Set it to a level slightly below your normal speaking volume.

9. You can also tweak the attack and release times if needed to fine-tune the noise gate's responsiveness.

10. Click on the "OK" button to apply the noise gate filter.

By using a noise gate filter, you can effectively suppress background noise in OBS Studio, ensuring a cleaner audio experience for your viewers.

paraphrase this The further you move the slider to the left, the 'stronger' the filter will be, and the more sounds it will filter out. Keep in mind that this can distort other sounds (like your voice)

As you slide the control towards the left, the filter's effectiveness increases, leading to the elimination of more sounds. However, it's important to note that excessive filtering can potentially distort other sounds, including your own voice.

PI control is widely used as a cascaded form of control in variable-speed motor drives. This approach involves applying PI controllers to the speed of the DTC drive and to the flux, torque, and speed of the DTC-SVM drive. Linear models were used as approximations of the real system, and metaheuristic techniques were applied offline to optimize the controller gains. For the speed loop, the Symmetrical Optimum Criterion was used to tune the gains. This approach was validated through simulations with the complete nonlinear model and practical experiments with the real system. In the speed control mode, a PID controller is used, with the input being the error between the reference speed and the actual speed of the motor. Anti-windup is utilized in the event of saturation to correctly adjust the integral action of the regulator. These findings are supported by works cited from Achalhi, Jnayah, and others. [achalhi2018] [15][16][jnayah2020][10.1016@j.asoc.2017.09.007].

The SVM method is implemented to generate pulses for the DC-AC inverter switches. This approach has several advantages, including a reduced number of switch commutations, lower harmonic content in the output voltage, a greater modulation index leading to better DC bus voltage, and easy implementation in microprocessors. The SVM algorithm used in this paper is based on an approach initially proposed by Kim and Sul in 1996. This approach has been further developed by Kanchan, Baiju, Mohapatra, Ouseph, and Gopakumar in 2005 and by Krishna, Amarnath, and Kamakshiah in 2012, particularly in terms of hardware implementation. The SVM-DTC operates at a constant switching frequency, while the DTC-SVM scheme illustrated in Figure 1 has speed, torque, and flux loops operating with PI controllers. Motor speed (ω_r) is sensed using a speed sensor that converts the mechanical speed into a corresponding voltage value compared with the reference speed (ω_r^*). The speed error is processed through a PI controller to generate the reference torque (Te*). The reference torque is compared with the estimated torque (Te) to generate the torque error (ΔTe), which is processed through a torque PI controller (Vq*). The estimated flux (Φs) is compared with the reference flux (Φs*), and the error (ΔΦs) is processed through a flux PI controller to generate (Vd*). Once (Vd*,Vq*) are obtained, a transformation of variables from the synchronous to stationary frame (α-β) using a (θ_s) estimator is carried out before injection into the SVM modulation block to generate the inverter control orders. Equations (1) and (2) describe the calculation to obtain the currents (Ia,Ib,Ic) and voltage (Va,Vb,Vc) generated from the inverter, which are then transformed into the stationary frame (d-q) to estimate torque, flux, and sector (Te, Φs, θ_s), as supported by works cited from Sudheer and others. [10.1016@j.conengprac.2019.05.003] [10.1016@j.asoc.2017.09.007] [1] [3,33,37-38].

As shown in Figure 1, there are two control loops corresponding to the stator flux and torque magnitudes. The reference values (Te*,Φs*) for the torque and the flux compared with the actual values (Φs, Te) to induce errors (∆Φs,∆Te). These errors feed into two hysteresis blocks, respectively. The outputs from the two hysteresis blocks and the stator flux position (S) are used as inputs to the switching table. The inverter is switched on using these errors and the position of the stator flux via six-region control. This results in the inverter operating in six-step operation with six active vectors and two zero vectors, as shown in Figure 3. The inverter output voltage vector is adjusted to minimize the flux and torque errors and define the direction of the flux rotation. [8599] [25] [29-31].

The middle Jurassic epoch was a significant geological period marked by major global geological events in Earth's history (Dera et al., 2011). First-order plate tectonics triggered the final breakup of Pangea and Gondwana, as well as subsequent continental rifting. These events led to the opening of new seaways and the initiation of seafloor spreading in the central Atlantic, the western Tethys, and large-scale oceanic corridors. Bartolini and Larson (2001) and Martini and Ortega-Gutierrez (2018) have provided evidence of this process. Additionally, research by Labails et al. (2010), Dera et al. (2015), and Scotese et al. (2021) has further elucidated the extent and impact of these geological events.

These events occurred concurrently with climate fluctuations that began during the late early Jurassic period. An important debate has emerged regarding the climate of the Jurassic period, particularly during the middle-late Jurassic transitional period. Some authors (Norris and Hallam, 1995; Jacquin et al., 1998; Hallam, 2001; Wierzbowski et al., 2009) consider this period as a global warming event, characterized by a significant sea-level rise (Wierzbowski et al., 2009; Wierzbowski and Rogov, 2011). These changes were driven by enhanced volcanic activity, tectonic uplift of oceanic ridges, and the reorganization of the seafloor oceanic spreading, which increased greenhouse gases and atmospheric CO2 concentration (Wierzbowski et al., 2009, 2012), and are believed to have caused the climate warming (Sellwood and Valdes, 2008; Holz et al., 2015). However, other studies (Dromart et al., 2003; Nunn, 2009; Price and Rogov, 2009; and Donnadieu et al., 2011) have suggested the opposite hypothesis. They propose that the middle-late Jurassic transitional period (160 Ma) may correspond to a severe "cooling event," with an abrupt global-scale fall of sea level suggestive of continental ice formation. Such changes are attributed to global cooling (Scotese et al., 2021).

Unraveling paleoenvironments and paleo-landscape evolution during the Jurassic of the western edge of the northwest Gondwana passive margin under paleoclimate changes during 26 Ma (Toarcian to Oxfordian) need an accurate and multidisciplinary analysis. In this foremost work, we attempt a paleogeographic and paleoclimatic reconstruction of Climate change during the early-late Jurassic. It has been generally accepted to use major and trace elements in sedimentary geology to assess paleoclimatic conditions and fluctuations during geological times (Cao et al., 2012; Armstrong-Altrin, 2020; Madhavaraju et al., 2020). Generally, elements such as Ca, Mg, K, Na, Sr, and Zn indicate arid climate, while others as Mg, Cu, Rb, Ba, Fe, Mn, V, Cr, Sr, Co, and Ni, display relatively enriched concentration in moist conditions (e.g., Ross and Bustin, 2009; Yandoka et al., 2015; Hu et al., 2016; El Mourabet et al., 2018; Liu and Zhou, 2007; Xiong and Xiao, 2011; Fu et al., 2018; Stankevica et al., 2020).

In order to accurately unravel the paleoenvironments and paleo-landscape evolution of the western edge of the northwest Gondwana passive margin during 26 Ma of paleoclimate changes spanning the Toarcian to Oxfordian periods, a comprehensive and interdisciplinary analysis is required. Through this primary investigation, we aim to reconstruct the paleogeographic and paleoclimatic changes that took place during the early-late Jurassic period. Major and trace elements in sedimentary geology have long been utilized as indicators of paleoclimatic conditions and fluctuations during geological times (Cao et al., 2012; Armstrong-Altrin, 2020; Madhavaraju et al., 2020). It is noteworthy to underline that the paleoenvironmental settings may directly influence the elemental concentrations in sediments and therefore, the recorded climatic conditions such as Sr (dry–type) and Rb, Cu (wet–type) are generally used to well constrain, and to interpret the paleoclimate features (Lerman, 1978; Liu and Zhou, 2007; Xiong and Xiao, 2011 ). The Rb/Sr, Sr/Cu, and Ga/Rb elemental ratios are used as useful indicators for the paleoclimate record (Xiong and Xiao, 2011; Cao et al., 2012; Roy and Roser, 2013; Yandoka et al., 2015; Cusack et al., 2020, Roy and Roser, 2013 a; He et al., 2017, Wang et al., 2022), and Rb/K and K/Al are used as proxies for chemical weathering intensity (McLennan et al., 1993, Schneider et al., 1997; Roy et al., 2008). Strontium (Sr) and barium (Ba) can provide insights into variations of paleo-salinity. The Sr/Ba ratio is supposed to increase with increasing salinity of ambient water (Epstein and Mayeda, 1953; Meng et al., 2012; Cao et al., 2015). Lerman et al. (1995) suggested a Sr/Cu ratio threshold values between~1.3 and ~5.0 which may reflect warm and humid climates, while those > 5.0 indicate drought conditions.

It is important to highlight that paleoenvironmental settings can directly impact the elemental concentrations found in sediments, and as a result, the recorded climatic conditions. For instance, Sr (dry-type) and Rb, Cu (wet-type) are commonly utilized to accurately constrain and interpret paleoclimate features (Lerman, 1978; Liu and Zhou, 2007; Xiong and Xiao, 2011). The Rb/Sr, Sr/Cu, and Ga/Rb elemental ratios have proven to be valuable indicators of paleoclimate records (Xiong and Xiao, 2011; Cao et al., 2012; Roy and Roser, 2013; Yandoka et al., 2015; Cusack et al., 2020; Roy and Roser, 2013a; He et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2022), while Rb/K and K/Al are widely used as proxies for assessing the intensity of chemical weathering (McLennan et al., 1993; Schneider et al., 1997; Roy et al., 2008). Meanwhile, the Sr/Ba ratio is an effective tool for identifying changes in paleo-salinity, with an increase in this ratio thought to indicate an increase in the salinity of ambient water (Epstein and Mayeda, 1953; Meng et al., 2012; Cao et al., 2015). Lerman et al., (1995) proposed threshold values for the Sr/Cu ratio of around ~1.3 to ~5.0, with values above 5.0 reflecting drought conditions, and those below 1.3 indicating warm and humid climates.

Hi Yiwen,

I wanted to summarize some important points regarding the dummy data for PK (Pharmacokinetics) and ADA (Anti-Drug Antibodies) for our study:

1) In any blinded study, only the active group will have PK and ADA samples tested. The placebo group will not have any PK and ADA samples tested.

2) Only the personnel from the BioA Lab will have access to unblinded information and will decide which samples to test. Again, the placebo group will not be tested.

3) Up until the occurrence of the study Clinical Data Lock (CDL), the study team will only have access to PK and ADA results for blinded studies.

4) Dummy data is prepared specifically for the purpose of the Dry Run. This includes both blinded and open-label studies. It should be noted that PK and ADA tests usually require more time due to their complex nature, involving methodology verification and sample QC. Therefore, it is common for these tests to not meet the timeline for the Dry Run. If real data is available within the Dry Run timeframe, it is acceptable for unblinded studies.

I hope this clarifies the important aspects of the dummy data for PK and ADA. If you have any further questions or concerns, please feel free to reach out to me.

Best regards, [Your Name]

Topic bundling involves grouping topics into bundles to achieve better scalability. Pulsar efficiently balances topic sessions by organizing them into bundle groups. This approach offers several advantages. Firstly, it reduces the cardinality of load samples for monitoring by aggregating topic load statistics at the bundle layer.
